A lot of twists and deaths. I feel like: There’s moving on with new stories and there’s disrespecting the past in order to get there. This movie isn’t bad; it’s well made and has excellent performances by Hamill and Driver. It is\, however\, a film that can only succeed by deconstruction. It must I make the characters we came to know and love before to move on. Do we become excited for new characters by making the old heroes into bitter shadows of their former selves? Is a story really well written if it requires its actors to completely go against their character’s motivations and morals to advance plot points? There is change and there is a blatant misunderstanding of what made the past so magical. This film quite literally thinks you must destroy the past to move on\, and it left me caring less about the current characters and their motivations as a result. What’s to stop another film from deconstructing Finn\, Poe\, and Rey? I don’t care that this film wants to change and move on. That’s commendable. I lament that it doesn’t understand Star Wars\, its characters\, its universe\, or its magic.
